page.aboutDescription: Supernetting (also called route aggregation or CIDR block aggregation) is the process of combining multiple smaller networks into a single larger network. This technique is essential for:

reducedRoutingTables.title: Reduced Routing Tables
reducedRoutingTables.description: Fewer routes mean faster lookups and reduced memory usage in routers

improvedScalability.title: Improved Scalability
improvedScalability.description: Internet routing scales better with aggregated routes instead of individual subnets

betterPerformance.title: Better Performance
betterPerformance.description: Reduced route advertisements and faster convergence in routing protocols

easierManagement.title: Easier Management
easierManagement.description: Simplified network policies and access control lists

ispRouteAggregation.title: ISP Route Aggregation
ispRouteAggregation.description: Combining customer routes for BGP advertisements

enterpriseNetworks.title: Enterprise Networks
enterpriseNetworks.description: Summarizing branch office networks at headquarters

dataCenters.title: Data Centers

networkRedesign.title: Network Redesign
networkRedesign.description: Optimizing existing IP allocations for better summarization

proTip.title: Pro Tip
proTip.description: For optimal supernetting, design your IP allocation strategy from the beginning. Contiguous, power-of-2 sized networks aggregate much more efficiently than scattered allocations.
